source.644aa729:
Scikitlearn is great! You can just get the general idea of what you need to do, google a couple of things, maybe read the documentation, adjust someone else's code and run things. At some point, however, you start asking yourself: what is it actually doing? is it doing what I think it is doing? 

Maybe you ask yourself this because you are curious, or maybe you would like to be sure that you are doing things right. Either way, if you were wondering about TfidfVectorizer(), this bit of code should help you get started on this. 

This piece came to be because I was wondering, out of necessity, rather than a sheer curiosity, what is happening if I want to vectorize a new text that was not in the fitted data. Of course, vectorizing a new text is not where I would stop, this vectorized thex will them by fed into a pre-trained model to make an out-of-sample prediction. But before I do that, I though it would be good to know, what is it that I would be feeding to my model. 

The code is a simple example and probably does not have too many new elements, however, hopefully, it saves the reader some time and brings this "aha, got it, now I can go on" moment a tiny bit closer.

source.aedd9152:
The following document contains two parts: 
1. **Toy Test**: I play with TfidfVectorizer on a very small toy data to make its functionality intuitivly transparent.
2. **Manual Calculation of tfidf**: I calculate some of the scores manually to replicate the results.
source.abbd7348: The scores are identical to those in x2, which means that the new "unknown" word is just ignored.
source.c6a6ec18: # **Converting new out of sample texts to TFIDF: what does Scikitlearn do?**
source.9f75b858: Now running a text that is identical to x2, with exception of one additional word that we do not have in the training set.
source.41d36c89: In following example any word appears only once in a specific text, so based on the formula (see link) tf = 1 everywhere. Therefore, we do not need to multiply tf and idf, and can just do caclualtions with idf(s).
source.93192493: **Calculating manually for out of sample example**: 'here is some text'
source.02e21744: Sometimes calculating stuff manually helps to understand what is actually going on, at least for me. Sktlearn has a few surprisis for you, if you just think you can look up tfidf formula and get to numbers' crunching. [Here](https://medium.com/analytics-vidhya/demonstrating-calculation-of-tf-idf-from-sklearn-4f9526e7e78b ) is some nice explanation of what Sktlearn actually does under the hood and how to replicate it.
source.61464750:
You've seen above that the vectors for the first and the second out of sample examples are identical, so the ways to calculate them would be the same as well - just ignoring the word not present in the training set. 

A, probably obvious, conclusion from this digging is that if you have many new (meaningfully important) words in the out of sample text, you are in trouble and need to retrain your vectorizer.
source.9b21c23d: Can replicate the tfidf score for a specific word if the all the words in the text are present as features and the word count is the same. For comparisson  example see line 0 in the training set and x2 vector.
